body: To the Editor: The article ''A Suburban Enclave in an Urban Setting'' [July 5], about Ditmas Park in Brooklyn, makes several references to a ''greater Ditmas Park,'' including on the accompanying map, and even quotes a homeowner in another neighborhood as saying that her own neighborhood ''should be placed under the Ditmas Park mantle 'unless you
title: Greater Ditmas Park Or West Midwood?

body: A PROBLEM of definition arises with Ditmas Park, an area of Flatbush known for jumbo-sized, richly detailed, nearly century-old Colonial Revival houses and ever-increasing ethnic diversity. In the strictest sense, Ditmas Park is made up of the Ditmas Park historic district, a few adjoining streets and a slightly less expensive companion
title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Ditmas Park, Brooklyn; A Suburban Enclave in an Urban Setting

body: CLARK HALSTEAD, founder of the real estate brokerage that bears his name, sees a certain similarity between the current quest for a rental apartment in New York City and the five stages of death and dying so poignantly delineated in Elisabeth Kubler-Ross's classic 1969 book on the subject: Denial. Anger. Bargaining. Depression. And, ultimately,
title: In 'Rent' 1998, the Renters Sing the Blues

body: A man accused of raping four women after posing as a plumber to gain entry to their apartments was arrested in Brooklyn yesterday after a crowd noticed him peeping into windows, the police said. The man, Asa Johnson, 46, of 611 Argyle Road in the Ditmas Park section of Brooklyn, was charged with the rapes of four women in his neighborhood since
title: Police Arrest Suspect In 4 Brooklyn Rapes

body: To the Editor: The tone of your criticism of New York City's tree maintenance and replacement track record flies in the face of my own experience with the Parks Department over the past three years (editorial, April 27). Our association began a program to replace the dead and dying (century-old) trees in our Brooklyn neighborhood in 1995. I
title: For Trees, Stresses of City Life Are Just Too Much; Fruitful Partnership
